My Jag-Stang History

Posted Feb 19th, 2024 by author
Baris Tosun
in the category "blog"

Adapted from a recent comment on reddit

I have a CIJ story that is similar to yours.

It was my second electric guitar ever, I was young so it was a gift from my parents. A CIJ Jag-Stang from the first (?) run. Ordered it from Japan too, since it wasn’t available anywhere else.

It arrived and the neck was damaged - seems like it bent in transit, but I corrected the angle. I took it to a luthier and get it set up.

I loved that guitar, I learned to play on my first guitar, but I developed my style on this one.

Gradually I became unhappy with it, something felt off, so I sought out solutions. The Mustang style electrics were limiting, so got the switches rewired. I bought a JB for the Bridge, an SJAG-3 for the neck. I had the neck shimmed, the bridge locked, the fretboard rolled.

I saw a red tortoise guard and I had to have it, and I took the Opportunity to add a three way switch. I wanted the humbucker to be straight, so I gauged the body until I could fit it that way.

I played, gigged and recorded on this guitar. It was MY guitar, but I deep down I couldn’t shake the feeling something was not right.

Last year I bought a couple of squier mustangs because they had the switching that I liked (and the price wasn’t too shitty either).

I bought the model with a maple fretboard; I always wanted one of those. I had a Mustang style vibrato/tailpiece that I wanted to use on this guitar, so I bought some tools and proceeded to modify the guitar. Long story short, I installed the bridge/vibrato, set it all up, and it plays like a dream, it holds tune, the strings align perfectly along the neck and over the pickup pole pieces. It dawned on me that all those years, the bridge on my Jag-Stang was mismatched, the spacing was incorrect, meaning the e strings were always close to the fretboard edges, making it harder to play up the neck.

On top of that, I realised after swapping necks with the new guitars (because they are all compatible), the neck pocket was falsely cut: it doesn’t correctly align with the bridge.

All in all, I can see now that the QC on that guitar was awful. I wonder if that neck being out on arrival was the cause of it, dooming it from day one. But I can’t say for sure.

I totally loved that guitar, still do. I was probably stubborn in trying to fix it rather than look for something to replace it, but we guitarists aren’t always rational, we get very sentimental about our instruments. With a rational head, I think that Jag-Stang is worthless and I’m compelled to buy a new body and move the parts across.

But that’s a hard bridge to cross man.

End of article
